article.title: turbulence
article.p:
turbulence
, In
fluid mechanics
, a flow condition (
see
turbulent
flow) in which local speed and pressure change unpredictably as an average flow is maintained. Common examples are wind and water swirling around obstructions, or fast flow (
Reynolds number
greater than 2,100) of any sort. Eddies, vortices, and a reduction in
drag
are characteristics of turbulence. Lowered drag enables golf balls to travel farther than they would do otherwise, and the dimpled surface of golf balls is meant to encourage turbulence in the
boundary
layer. If swimsuits with rough surfaces help swimmers to move faster, as has been claimed, the same explanation may apply.
